physDesc.p: Two pages typewritten in black ink. Address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page: Mrs. Richard Aldington c/o Manager, Lloyd’s Bank, 67 Kingsway, London W.C.2. England. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Here are our half-yearly Imagist Anthology royalties: By Sales 19 Imagist Poets .67-1/2 $12.32 12 “ 1916 .67-1/2 8.10 13 “ 1917 .67-1/2 8.77 $29.69 1/6 of $29.69 is……$4.95 I should have sent them in August, and I feel very guilty that I did not do so. Nothing but the smallness of the sum seems to excuse my dilatoriness, but the truth is I have been so drowned in this Keats book that I have hardly gotten out of it for a moment. You will forgive me, won’t you?

I do not know where you are or what you are doing. Do write and tell me about everything, and do let me know where Winifred Bryher is. I sent her a whole batch of unpublished poems the other day – really about two months ago – and I have not heard a word from her to say that she has received it. I sent it as usual to South Audley Street, where she always tells me to address her as the surest place. I suppose she has gone to the Parnirs, of the South Sea Islands, or the North Pole, or somewhere, and the package is awaiting her return home. Whatever you know about here, do tell me, and tell me everything you are doing. I understand that Houghton Mifflin are to issue your books next year; at least, so Ferris Greenslet told me a little while ago. I shall be delighted to have them in print, for I should like to send a number of copies around for Christmas.

There is precious little news here. I have been hard at work all Summer over my Keats book, and have hardly been away from home. I have just been in New York for two weeks, and am going there again next week to give some lectures, but I am minimizing my lectures this year in order that I may devote all my time to Keats. Getting him through the press will prevent my going abroad this Summer, and sometimes it really seems as though I should never go abroad again; but, of course, I know that is not true, I might just possess my soul in patience.

I am awfully anxious to hear all about you. It seems so long since I have had a letter, and I hate to get out of touch with you. It is one of the advantages of the Imagist anthologies that I have to send the royalties to you every six months. Lots of love, my dear, from both Ada and me, and write soon.
